As for discussing repentance, it is originally about changing past actions, cultivating future ones, extinguishing evil, and promoting goodness.

When a person lives in the world, who can be without faults? Even learners who forget their intentions still give rise to afflictions. Arhats' habitual tendencies move their bodily and verbal actions. How could ordinary beings be without faults?
But the wise first realize and can then change and repent. The foolish conceal and let them proliferate. Therefore, accumulated habits last for a long time and there is no hope of enlightenment.

If one is able to feel shame and remorse, confess and repent, not only will one be able to extinguish one's offenses, but one will also increase immeasurable merit and establish the wonderful fruit of the TathÄgata's nirvÄá¹‡a.

If one wishes to practice this method, one should first externally regulate one's appearance and revere the honored image, internally arouse respectful thoughts and contemplate the characteristics of the Dharma, with sincere and earnest intent give rise to two kinds of thoughts.
What are the two?
First, reflect on oneself, thinking that this body and life are difficult to preserve permanently, and suddenly disintegrate, not knowing when this body may be restored;
If one does not encounter the buddhas and sages, one suddenly encounters evil friends and creates various offenses, and should again fall into deep pits and perilous destinies.

Second, reflect on yourself and think: Although in this life I have encountered the TathÄgata's true Dharma and become a Buddha's disciple, the duty of a disciple is to inherit the holy lineage, purify body, speech, and mind, and abide in the good Dharma. Yet now we ourselves openly commit evil and then conceal it, thinking that others do not know and that they do not see it. We hide it in our hearts and are arrogant without shame. This is truly the most foolish and deluded in the world.

Now there are presently the Buddhas of the ten directions, the bodhisattvas of the great earth, and the celestial spirits and immortals, who have never failed to see the evil deeds we have done with their pure celestial eyes.
Moreover, the spirits of the unseen world record merits and demerits, not missing even the slightest detail.
As for those who commit crimes, after their lives end, the jailers of the ox-headed guards record their spirits and bring them before King Yama to discern right from wrong.
At that time, all their enemies come to bear witness and each says:
'You previously slaughtered me, roasting and boiling my body.
' Some say:
'You previously stripped me of all my wealth and separated me from my relatives. I have only now obtained my chance to get you back.'

At that time, the evidence right in front of them, how could they dare to deny it? They can only willingly accept their share of the retribution from past calamities, as explained in the sutras, not unjustly punishing people in the hells.
If in their previous lives, they have lost track of the many crimes they have committed, all the images of the places where they created evil in their previous lives will appear before them.
Each says:
'You previously committed such and such crimes in my presence. How can you deny it now?'
This is because there is no place to hide the crimes one has committed.
Then King Yama will gnash his teeth in rebuke and hand them over to the hells. They will pass through kalpas and exhaust their years, seeking to escape but finding no way out.

This matter is not far away, nor does it concern others, it is precisely my own body creating and experiencing [the consequences] myself. We all have a body and are free from many illnesses, each of us should strive with all our effort, fearing for our lives. When death is about to arrive, it is too late to regret.
